![](https://www.italpassion.fr/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/ferrari-f80-2.jpg)
**The limited edition of [the Ferrari F80](https://www.italpassion.fr/en/tag/ferrari-f80/)** the new successor model to the legendary F40, F50 and LaFerrari, **is already an object of desire for the wealthiest collectors**. But it seems that the craze surrounding this hypercar is not limited to the privileged customers of [Ferrari](https://www.italpassion.fr/en/ferrari/). A German seller recently tried to make a spectacular profit by offering to buy an example of the F80 before it was even produced. A few weeks after publication, the ad mysteriously disappeared.
## A dream offer, but at what price?
To understand the scope of this affair, we first need to look back at the exclusivity of the Ferrari F80. Even before its official presentation, [the entire production run of this hypercar had already been snapped up](https://www.italpassion.fr/en/ferrari/ferrari-f80-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-most-powerful-road-going-ferrari-of-all-time/). **Only the most loyal Ferrari customers, who have already purchased several of the brand's models, were invited to place an order.**. It has to be said that to afford such a car, it's not enough to have a colossal fortune; you also have to earn the manufacturer's trust. But some customers, although financially capable, were excluded from the market because they didn't meet the exclusivity criteria imposed by Ferrari.
Advertising
![](https://www.italpassion.fr/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/ferrari-f80-occasion-2.jpg)
This is where German investment specialist KB-Lease Invest GmbH comes in. **The latter had the idea of putting one of the 799 examples of the F80 up for sale.** But not just any car: a brand-new vehicle, for which the order form is still available and for which the future owner can even choose the configuration. **All this for the modest sum of 6 million euros, a far cry from the starting price of 3.6 million euros set by Ferrari.** not including customization costs.
## Are the risks worth it?
While the offer may seem tempting to a collector eager to obtain a Ferrari F80, it raised a number of questions. **Ferrari, well known for its strict approach to the sale of its hypercars,** does not usually allow legal entities such as KB-Lease Invest to resell such exclusive models directly. The company could therefore act as an intermediary, but this does not prevent it from **a potential retaliation by Ferrari against this attempt at speculation.**
Advertising
The Italian manufacturer is keen to maintain the exclusive character of its models, **has strict rules concerning the resale of its vehicles.** For example, to discourage speculators, some buyers have to commit to keeping their car for a certain number of years before reselling it. This was the case with boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr. who, after putting his Ferrari up for sale just a few months after buying it, was removed from the brand's list of potential customers.
![](https://www.italpassion.fr/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/ferrari-f80-occasio.jpg)
**In the case of this F80 resale announcement, it's highly likely that Ferrari was quick to react.** A few weeks after the ad was published on the Mobile.de website, it mysteriously disappeared. Either the seller found a buyer willing to pay top dollar, or Ferrari intervened to prohibit the transaction.
Advertising
## A lesson in exclusivity from Ferrari
The incident surrounding the sale of this Ferrari F80 purchase order recalls **the importance the manufacturer places on the exclusivity of its models.** Beyond simply selling cars, Ferrari cultivates a carefully nurtured brand image. Each model is a work of art reserved for a select clientele. The story of this example of the F80 shows that, even in the world of high-end automobiles, the influence of Ferrari and its strict sales rules should not be underestimated.

Below is a structured “deal-memo” style assessment of the trade you are contemplating. Figures are indicative; update them with your own quotes and tax rates before acting.
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── 1. ECONOMIC RETURN VS. LOAN COST ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
A. Basic numbers • Factory list (incl. standard options)……………… €3.60 m • Customisation allowance (typical)………………… +0.20 m • Delivery, local VAT/registration (DE 19 %)……… +0.74 m • All-in cash cost on day one…………………………… €4.54 m
B. Debt structure considered • Bank loan (80 % LTV)…………………………………… €3.63 m • Your equity (20 %)……………………………………… €0.91 m • Fixed rate coupon……………………………………… 3.0 % • Tenor……………………………………………………… Interest-only for 24 mo, bullet at maturity • Annual debt service…………………………………… €108 k
C. Exit assumption • Target resale price (+20 %)………………………… €5.45 m • Selling fee (5 % broker & auction)……………… –0.27 m • Net sale proceeds……………………………………… €5.18 m
D. Pre-tax profit & IRR (24-month hold) • Gross gain…………………………………… 5.18 – 4.54 = €0.64 m • Loan interest (2 yrs)…………………………… –0.22 m • Insurance, storage, upkeep (~40 k / yr)…… –0.08 m • Net cash profit……………………………………… €0.34 m • Cash-on-cash IRR on €0.91 m equity…… ≈ 17 % p.a.
Break-even resale premium = ~10 % (anything below that and you lose money after costs).
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── 2. LIQUIDITY & DEBT-SERVICE COVERAGE ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
• Annual outflow is ~€148 k (interest 108 k + running 40 k). • Ensure recurring, *independent* income that covers at least 2× that number—banks will look for a Debt-Service-Coverage-Ratio (DSCR) >1.2 anyway. • Bullet repayment risk: after 24 mo you must either (i) refinance, (ii) sell, or (iii) inject cash. A forced sale in a thin market is your single largest liquidity hazard.
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── 3. MARKET & EXECUTION RISK ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
• Allocation risk: Ferrari often contractually bars transfer before first registration; if you are not the “approved” client, the order can be cancelled at their discretion. • Hold period: past hyper-Ferraris carried a 12- to 24-mo no-sale clause; breach can void warranty and black-list you. • Depth of bid: only ~799 cars, but the buyer pool willing to pay >€5 m is perhaps a few dozen globally. One extra month of waiting adds another ~€9 k interest cost. • Macro correlation: illiquid assets trade off sharply in recessions (2008, 2020 auction data show –15 % to –30 % hammer-price declines).
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── 4. TRANSACTION & HOLDING COSTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
• VAT: 19 % in Germany on first registration, *non-recoverable* for private buyers; foreigners may avoid it by exporting immediately—confirm with counsel. • Import duties if buyer is outside EU (2.5 % cars, 15 % super-luxury in China). • Insurance: €15-25 k/year for agreed-value cover. • Storage: €5-10 k/year (climate-controlled). • Maintenance: minor (warranty), but servicing to keep warranty intact is mandatory (~€4 k/year). • Exit fees: Sotheby’s, Bonhams etc. charge 5–6 % from seller plus 12–15 % buyer premium (affects achievable headline price).
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── 5. OPPORTUNITY COST ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
• Deploying €0.91 m equity elsewhere at a conservative 6 % IRR (private credit, balanced portfolio) yields ~€112 k/year. Netting that, your “alpha” shrinks to ~€80 k a year. • Concentration: 100 % of the bet sits in one VIN; a diversified portfolio with identical expected return but lower standard deviation is mathematically superior.
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── 6. LOAN COVENANTS & STRUCTURAL RISK ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
• Collateral: Bank will take first-charge on the title; if Ferrari vetoes title transfer or registration, collateral perfection becomes shaky and lender may withdraw. • Early repayment: typical 0.5–1.0 % make-whole. • MAC (Material Adverse Change) clauses could pull the facility if luxury-car prices drop or your personal net worth falls. • Personal guarantee almost always required above €1 m.
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── DECISION TREE SUMMARY ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Ferrari allows transfer? ── Yes ── Market ≥ €5.0m? ── Yes ── You clear €0.3–0.4m │ │ └── No → Loan collapses └── No → Forced sale/breach, likely loss €0.2–1.0m
Probability-weighted outcome (subjective):
• 60 % smooth exit → +€0.35 m • 25 % delayed sale / lower price (break-even) → €0 • 15 % covenant breach / compulsory discount sale → –€0.50 m
Expected value ≈ +€0.12 m on €0.91 m equity → ~4 % annualised after risk-adjustment—barely ahead of a low-risk portfolio and far behind moderate-risk alternatives.
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── BOTTOM LINE ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Purely as an investment, the trade is marginal:
• The *headline* IRR (≈17 % p.a.) looks attractive, but evaporates once you haircut for execution and market risk. • Liquidity mismatch (bullet loan vs. illiquid asset) is a non-trivial tail risk. • Ferrari’s enforceable anti-flipping clauses make the 20 % upside far from certain.
Therefore the purchase only makes sense if you put material *utility value* on owning the car (brand access, personal enjoyment, business signalling). If the goal is strictly financial, deploy your equity in a diversified portfolio or private credit fund offering 7–10 % with lower variance.
Consult a specialist automotive attorney and an independent tax adviser before committing.

Below is a structured, “line-by-line” way to think about your proposed transaction. You can plug in your own numbers (holding period, deposit size, fees, tax‐rate, etc.) into the template and stress‐test it under different scenarios.
1. Set up a simple cash‐flow model • Purchase price = P₀ (€6 million) • Equity/deposit = E (say 20 % × P₀ = €1.2 M) • Bank loan = L = P₀–E (€4.8 M) at r = 3 % p.a. • Holding period = T (e.g. 1 year) • Resale price target = P₁ = P₀ × (1 + g) where g = 20 % → P₁ = €7.2 M
2. Net Return on Investment a) Interest cost on loan: I = L × r × T = €4.8 M × 3 % × 1 = €144 k b) Gross sales proceeds: P₁ = €7.2 M c) Net profit before fees/taxes = (P₁ – P₀) – I = (€1.2 M – €144 k) = €1.056 M d) Transaction & holding costs (see #4 below) – call this C. e) Capital‐gains tax (if any) at rate t: Tax = [(P₁–P₀) – C] × t f) Net profit to equity = €1.056 M – C – Tax
IRR (approx on equity E): IRR ≈ [Net profit to equity / E] × 100 %
Example (ballpark): C = €200 k total fees/insurance/etc., t = 25 % Profit before tax = €1.056 M – €200 k = €856 k Tax = 25 % × €856 k = €214 k Net = €642 k IRR ≈ €642 k/€1.2 M ≈ 53.5 %
3. Liquidity Management – Tie-up of E = €1.2 M plus any working capital for fees & insurance. – Check covenants: collateral posted = the car. Repo risk if you miss interest. – Ability to service interest from cash flow or reserves, without selling other assets. – Emergency buffer: if resale stalls or premium shrinks, can you meet interim payments?
4. Transaction & Holding Costs • Acquisition fees, transfer tax, registration (often 10–15 % of P₀ in Europe) • Customs/import duties (if shipped) • Insurance (collector’s policy ~1–2 % of insured value p.a.) • Storage, maintenance, depreciation risk (tires, battery conditioning) • Broker/dealer commission on sale (2–5 %) • Capital‐gains or VAT offset (depends on jurisdiction)
Build a detailed line‐item schedule for each cost and amortize over T.
5. Market Risk & Timing – Is the 20 % premium based on comparable sales or merely hope? – Time‐to-liquidate: 1 month vs. 1 year vs. 3 years → carrying costs rise. – Ferrari’s resale restrictions: mandatory holding period, “right-of-first-refusal,” or risk of Ferrari blocking resale. – Scenario analysis: g = +10 %, +20 %, +30 %, and downside g = 0 %, –5 %.
6. Opportunity Cost Compare your net IRR from the F80 deal to alternative uses of E: – Public equities (S&P 500 ~8–10 % p.a.) – Private real-estate or private equity (12–15 % p.a.) – High-yield bonds or money-market (3–5 %) – Cash buffer (<1 %)
If your stress‐cases (g = +10 % or g = +5 %) yield net IRR below your hurdle rate, rethink.
7. Loan Terms & Repayment Flexibility – Early‐repayment penalties? If the sale closes before T, can you prepay without fee? – Margin calls or additional collateral requirements if LTV > certain threshold. – Default interest rate bumps (from 3 % to 6 %+) and their impact on your downside. – What happens if Ferrari enforces a 2–3 year lock‐in on resale?
8. Putting It All Together—“Go/No-Go” A. Base-case (g = 20 %, T = 1 yr): • Net IRR vs. hurdle rate • Liquidity buffer sufficiency • Loan flexibility OK? B. Downside (g = 10 %, T = 1 yr) C. Bear-case (g = 0 %, T = 2 yrs)
If in B or C your IRR falls below your cost of capital, or you breach covenants/tie up too much liquidity, the deal breaks.
9. Final Recommendations • Only proceed if you can: – Lock in a binding resale agreement (or non-refundable deposit from a buyer) at your target price. – Negotiate loan terms that allow penalty-free early repayment and tight collateral limits. – Quantify every fee, tax and insurance line item up front. – Maintain a cash buffer equal to at least the interest cost + 20 % of E in case of delays. • Run a weekly/monthly mark-to-market on comparable sales to track your probability of achieving the 20 % premium. • If you don’t get strong commitment on resale by Month 3, be prepared to walk away—cost of capital can quickly turn a profitable plan into a loss.
By building your own “plug-and-play” spreadsheet on the above six dimensions, you’ll turn a speculative, emotion-driven idea into a disciplined, numbers-driven decision.

# Comprehensive Analysis: Ferrari F80 Investment Decision
## Executive Summary
Based on the provided information, purchasing a Ferrari F80 using a bank loan at 3% with expectations of a 20% premium resale appears to be a **high-risk investment proposition with significant uncertainties**. The absence of key financial details and the presence of substantial market restrictions severely limit the viability of this investment strategy.
## Detailed Factor Analysis
### 1. Net Return on Investment - **Proposed Purchase Mechanism**: 3% bank loan - **Expected Return**: 20% premium on resale - **Key Concerns**: - The article indicates the F80 is priced at €3.6 million from Ferrari, but resellers are attempting to charge €6 million (a 67% markup, not 20%) - No timeline is provided for achieving this return, making ROI calculations incomplete - The 17% net return (20% premium minus 3% loan cost) doesn't account for holding costs or transaction fees
### 2. Market Risk (Critical Factor) - **Manufacturer Intervention**: Ferrari actively prevents speculation - The article explicitly mentions a German reseller's listing was "mysteriously disappeared" - Ferrari enforces holding periods before resale is permitted - Previous speculators (e.g., Floyd Mayweather Jr.) have been blacklisted from future purchases - **Allocation Restrictions**: Ferrari only sells to loyal customers with purchase history - You cannot simply purchase with available financing; you must be selected by Ferrari - The article states "only the most loyal Ferrari customers... were invited to place an order" - **Market Volatility**: The projected 20% premium is highly speculative and unsubstantiated
### 3. Liquidity Management - Tying up significant capital in a vehicle that cannot be legally resold for a potentially extended period creates a severe liquidity constraint - No information is provided on required down payment or loan terms - Forced holding periods would extend your liquidity constraint timeline
### 4. Transaction & Holding Costs - No mention of: - Insurance costs for a multi-million euro vehicle - Storage requirements and costs - Maintenance requirements - Registration fees and taxes - Potential depreciation if market conditions change
### 5. Opportunity Cost - Capital tied up in a non-liquid asset with resale restrictions - No comparative analysis provided for alternative investments - Potential loss of future Ferrari purchase opportunities if you violate their terms
### 6. Bank Loan Considerations - No information on: - Collateral requirements - Loan term structure - Early repayment penalties - Bank's willingness to finance a speculative purchase
## Critical Barriers to Execution
1. **Allocation Eligibility**: The most significant barrier is simply obtaining an allocation. The article clearly states the entire production run is already sold out to Ferrari's most loyal customers.
2. **Resale Restrictions**: Ferrari actively prevents speculation by imposing holding periods and blacklisting violators.
3. **Market Risk**: The projected 20% premium appears unrealistic when compared to the current speculative pricing mentioned in the article (67% markup).
## Recommendation
Based on the available information, this investment opportunity appears **highly inadvisable** for several reasons:
1. You likely cannot obtain an allocation without an existing relationship with Ferrari 2. Attempting to purchase for speculation violates Ferrari's policies 3. The investment timeline is unclear and potentially extended 4. The projected return may not compensate for the associated risks and costs 5. Ferrari actively works to prevent exactly this type of transaction
A more prudent approach would be to: - Consider alternative investment vehicles with clearer terms and fewer restrictions - If interested in automotive investments, research models with established resale markets and without manufacturer restrictions - Build a relationship with Ferrari through standard vehicle purchases if exotic car investment is a long-term goal

Okay, let's rigorously evaluate the proposed purchase of a Ferrari F80 for speculative resale, using the factors you've outlined and integrating the crucial context provided by the linked article.
The core premise is to acquire a Ferrari F80, likely at a certain cost, finance it via a 3% loan, hold it for some period, and then resell it at a 20% premium to the *acquisition cost*. This is being considered under current liquidity constraints.
Here's a breakdown based on your factors and the provided information:
**Crucial Context from the Provided Article:**
The article highlights that the Ferrari F80 is: 1. A limited edition hypercar (799 units), already sold out to loyal Ferrari customers *at the list price* (€3.6 million + customization). 2. Highly exclusive, requiring a history of purchasing previous models to even be offered one directly from Ferrari. 3. Subject to Ferrari's strict anti-speculation rules. They are known to: * Require buyers to commit to holding the car for a certain number of years. * Blacklist individuals who attempt quick resales (like Floyd Mayweather Jr.). * Actively intervene to prevent or stop speculative flipping. 4. An attempted resale of a purchase order for €6 million (a significant premium over the €3.6 million list price) was recently made but the ad "mysteriously disappeared," strongly implying Ferrari intervention to prevent this type of transaction.
This context is **absolutely critical** and severely impacts the feasibility of your plan. You are not a loyal customer getting the car at list price, and Ferrari actively works to prevent the exact scenario you are proposing.
**Evaluation of Factors:**
1. **Net Return on Investment:** * **Your Premise:** Loan Interest Cost vs. Expected Resale Profit (20% premium). * **Rigorous Analysis:** * **Acquisition Cost:** This is the first major uncertainty. The article shows the list price is €3.6M, but only loyal customers got it. To acquire one now, you would likely have to buy a purchase order or an early-delivery slot on the secondary market, potentially paying a *significant premium* over list price, possibly in the range of the attempted €6M purchase (€2.4M or ~66% premium over list, based on the article). Your 20% *resale* premium is based on an *assumed* acquisition cost, but that cost itself is unknown and likely very high, eroding the potential profit margin from the start. * **Loan Cost:** A 3% annual yield is known. However, the *duration* over which this cost accrues is highly uncertain. If Ferrari forces a multi-year holding period, the total interest paid will be substantial. * **Resale Price Certainty:** The article provides direct evidence that achieving a premium (even a much higher one than 20%) through quick resale is *actively opposed* by Ferrari. Your expected 20% premium is highly speculative and faces significant resistance from the manufacturer. There's a substantial risk you *cannot* sell at a premium, or even recoup your (potentially inflated) acquisition cost, at least not within a reasonable timeframe without incurring Ferrari's ire. * **Other Costs (Factor 4):** Transaction fees, taxes, insurance, storage, and potential maintenance will further reduce any potential net return. These costs for a hypercar are very high. * **Conclusion for Factor 1:** The net return calculation is based on highly uncertain variables (acquisition cost, achievable resale price/timing, total holding period). The provided article strongly suggests that the expected 20% premium is unlikely to be achievable quickly due to Ferrari's policies, making the projected profit highly dubious. The substantial loan costs and other expenses would likely outweigh any potential (and uncertain) resale gain, potentially leading to a significant *loss*.
2. **Liquidity Management:** * **Your Premise:** Ability to cover short-term obligations while capital is tied up. * **Rigorous Analysis:** * **Capital Tie-up:** A multi-million euro asset (€3.6M+ acquisition cost) will tie up a huge amount of capital. * **Ongoing Costs:** Loan repayments (interest and potentially principal), insurance, storage, and other holding costs require significant ongoing cash flow, putting direct pressure on your liquidity constraints. * **Resale Uncertainty & Timing (Linked to Factor 3 & Article):** Because Ferrari may prevent or delay your ability to resell the car, the capital could be tied up for a much longer period than anticipated. This extended holding time exacerbates liquidity pressures due to prolonged loan and holding costs. If you face a liquidity crunch while the car is held, you might be forced into a distressed sale, potentially at a significant loss, or face loan default. * **Conclusion for Factor 2:** This venture poses an *extreme* risk to liquidity. The high upfront capital requirement, substantial ongoing costs, and significant uncertainty surrounding the timing and success of the resale (directly influenced by Ferrari's actions) mean your capital could be illiquid for an unpredictable duration, making it very difficult to manage short-term obligations under existing constraints.
3. **Market Risk:** * **Your Premise:** Certainty and timing of achieving the projected 20% selling price premium. * **Rigorous Analysis:** * **Certainty of Premium:** As detailed under Factor 1, the article provides strong evidence (the failed €6M ad) that Ferrari actively works to prevent such speculative premiums immediately after purchase. The certainty of achieving *any* premium, let alone 20%, within a timeframe that makes the venture financially viable, is very low. The market for flipping newly delivered hypercars is highly controlled by the manufacturer. * **Timing:** Ferrari's potential imposition of holding periods means you might be *unable* to sell the car for several years without risking blacklisting or other repercussions from Ferrari. This completely undermines the idea of a relatively quick flip to capitalize on immediate demand. * **Conclusion for Factor 3:** The market risk related to achieving the desired premium and timing is exceptionally high, primarily due to Ferrari's strict rules and willingness to intervene against speculative transactions. The provided article serves as a direct warning about the difficulty of executing this strategy.
